questions.text: The Cobra Head sign is seen in
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Ureterocele The classic sign of a ureterocele on excretion urography was of a ‘cobra head’ but intravenous urography (IVU) is relatively infrequently undertaken nowadays

Highyeild:

Ureterocoele A ureterocoele is a cystic enlargement of the intramural ureter, probably due to atresia of the ureteric orifice. Incidence : Ureterocoeles affect females more often than males (4:1) and 10% are bilateral. Presentation & Diagnosis : In childhood, they usually present with infection. When large, they can obstruct the bladder neck or even the contralateral ureteric orifice. In adults, ureterocoeles typically present with stones in the lower ureter. The classic sign of a ureterocoele on excretion urography was of a ‘cobra head’ but intravenous urography (IVU) is relatively infrequently undertaken nowadays. On cystoscopy, a bulging, translucent swelling involving the ureteric orifice is typical which fills with and empties of urine with ureteric peristalsis. Treatment Treatment of simple ureterocoeles is surgical excision with re-implantation of the ureter. The endoscopic incision is a relatively straightforward method of releasing a stone stuck in a ureterocoele but may result in subsequent ureteric reflux. A non-functioning kidney may need a nephrectomy.

questions.text: Identify the condition shown in the image
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Sebaceous cyst The image shows a Sebaceous cyst of the scrotum. Sebaceous cysts are common in the scrotal skin . They are usually small and multiple . If troublesome, then surgical excision is necessary.

Highyeild:

These cysts are lined with true stratified squamous epithelium, derived from hair follicle infundibuli or traumatic inclusion. Commonly known as sebaceous cysts, they can occur anywhere . They are fixed to the skin and usually have a central punctum Treatment: When inflamed or infected, they should be incised and drained initially; they should be removed later once the inflammation and induration have subsided. It is important to excise the cyst in its entirety as failure to do so usually results in recurrence Another related cyst: Meibomian cysts are epidermal cysts found on the free edge of the eyelid. Trichilemmal (pilar/pilosebaceous) cysts are derived from the epidermis of the external root sheath of the hair follicle

questions.correct_answer: A. Non-muscle invasive bladder cancer does not invade the detrusor muscle and lamina propria
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Non-muscle invasive bladder cancer does not invade the detrusor muscle and lamina propria Non-muscle-invasive bladder cancer (NMIBC) does not invade the detrusor muscle but can extend to the lamina propria

Highyeild:

Non-muscle-invasive bladder cancer (NMIBC) : Does not invade the detrusor muscle but can extend to the lamina propria Extension to the lamina propria (pT1) is a significant risk factor for progression to invasive disease, especially if associated with high-grade disease and carcinoma in situ The incidence of recurrence of this disease can be reduced by intravesical chemotherapy and immunotherapy High-risk superficial disease (any grade 3 disease) is best managed by Bbacille Calmette–Guérin immunotherapy followed by radical treatment if the disease persists. Muscle-invasive bladder cancer: Muscle-invasive bladder cancer (MIBC) should be staged by an accurate bimanual examination performed under anaesthesia before and after resection of the tumour Complete urinary tract assessment should be performed, including CT, MR and IV urography, as well as cross-sectional imaging to identify lymph node involvement and distant spread Radical primary treatment options include radical cystectomy, urinary diversion and thorough lymph node dissection, which tends to be offered as first-line, or radical external beam radiotherapy Neoadjuvant chemotherapy improves survival rates as well as adjuvant chemotherapy in some cases, particularly in the presence of nodal and distant diseases. Locally advanced disease may be downstaged by radiotherapy or chemotherapy to enable salvage cystectomy.

questions.text: The most common congenital urethral anomaly is
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Hypospadias Hypospadias: Hypospadias occurs in around 1 in 200–300 male live births and is the most common congenital abnormality of the urethra. There are three characteristic features. The external meatus opens on the underside of the penis anywhere from just short of the normal site as far back as the perineum, While the ventral aspect of the prepuce is poorly developed (the ‘hooded prepuce’) There is usually a ventral deformity of the erect penis (chordee) . Classification : Glanular Coronal Penile Penoscrotal Perineal Treatment : Avoid circumcision as the prepuce may be used in procedures to correct the abnormality Surgical treatment should be undertaken by experts The first stage corrects the penile curvature and the second stage repairs the urethra

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Epispadias is very rare. In penile epispadias, the urethral opening is on the dorsum of the penis and is associated with an upward curvature of the erect penis. Option: B. Bladder exstrophy occurs in 1:50 000 births (male: female ratio 4:1). In males, the penis is broad and short, and a bilateral inguinal hernia may be present. There is the separation of the pubic bones. In epispadias alone, the pubes are united and external genitalia are almost normal, although in females the clitoris is bifid.

Solution:

Peyronie's disease While the aetiology of Peyronie’s disease is uncertain, there is an association with Dupuytren’s contracture. The natural history of the condition is that it typically progresses for 18–24 months before stabilizing. Palmar fibromatosis (Dupuytren’s contracture), plantar fibromatosis and penile fibromatosis (Peyronie’s disease) are components of the same pathological process called superficial fibromatosis

Highyeild:

Peyronie’s disease : Peyronie’s disease is characterized by penile deformity, palpable penile plaques within the penis, ED and pain on erection. The cause is unknown but probably involves minor injury to the erect penis with secondary micro haemorrhage beneath the tunica albuginea and secondary fibrosis. The latter results in palpable plaques that can be identified on examination. The plaques may rarely be calcified. The presence of these relatively inelastic plaques causes the erect penis to bend, often dramatically, towards the side of the plaque. The commonest direction of deformity is dorsally (towards the abdomen) and the deformity may be so great as to prevent penetrative sexual intercourse. While the aetiology is uncertain, there is an association with Dupuytren’s contracture. The natural history of the condition is that it typically progresses for 18–24 months before stabilizing. During this acute (or active) phase of the disease, surgery is not indicated, and a variety of medical treatments have been tried, although none with any good evidence of benefit.

questions.text: Staging of Penile carcinoma extending up to the urethra is
questions.explanation:
Solution:

T3 T3 tumours invade the urethra

Highyeild:

Carcinoma of the penis is most typically a squamous cell carcinoma arising in the skin of the glans penis or the prepuce. It may be flat and infiltrating or warty in appearance. The former often starts as leukoplakia or Penile Intraepithelial neoplasia and the latter results from an existing papilloma. Local growth continues for months or years. T1 tumours are confined to the skin, with T2 tumours invading the corpus spongiosum or the corpus cavernosum. T3 tumours invade the urethra and T4 tumours invade adjacent structures. The earliest lymphatic spread is to the inguinal (N1 and N2 disease) and then to the iliac nodes (N3 disease). Distant metastatic deposits are infrequent.

Extraedge:

When they are involved in CT scanning, surgery probably has a little role; however, when the iliac nodes are not enlarged in the presence of N2 disease, the options are observation, pelvic lymphadenectomy or radiotherapy The prognosis for tumours confined to the penis is good with 5-year survival rates in excess of 80%. With nodal involvement, the 5-year survival rate falls to around 40%

questions.text: Treatment of choice of small preputial penile carcinoma is
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Wide excision For the primary tumour surgical excision is the mainstay of treatment , with the traditional view that a 2 cm margin of normal tissue be removed being superseded by a more recent, more conservative view, such that penile preserving surgery with excision of much lower margins of normal tissue are now accepted

Highyeild:

Treatment- Carcinoma penis : Management is divided into treatment of the primary tumour and treatment of the inguinal nodes. For the primary tumour surgical excision is the mainstay of treatment , with the traditional view that a 2 cm margin of normal tissue be removed being superseded by a more recent, more conservative view, such that penile preserving surgery with excision of much lower margins of normal tissue are now accepted. Tumours affecting the glans penis require glansectomy , with more advanced tumours requiring partial penectomy . In advanced cases, total penectomy is required with the formation of perineal urethrostomy . Such surgery is indicated even in advanced metastatic disease for reasons of local control. Treatment of any associated enlarged inguinal lymph nodes should be delayed until at least 3 weeks after local treatment of the primary lesion. Enlargement caused by infection will usually show signs of subsiding with antibiotic treatment. For palpable nodes, ultrasound-guided fine needle aspiration will confirm the diagnosis and a block dissection of both groins should be undertaken. The management of patients where the nodes are not palpable disease involves the use of sentinel lymph node biopsy (SLNB) followed by inguinal node dissection if the SLNB is positive. Management of the pelvic nodes is controversial. When they are involved in CT scanning, surgery probably has a little role, but when the iliac nodes are not enlarged in the presence of N2 disease, the options are observation, pelvic lymphadenectomy or radiotherapy. Chemotherapy is relatively ineffective and currently is reserved for palliation in those with metastatic disease. The prognosis for tumours confined to the penis is good with 5-year survival rates in excess of 80%. With nodal involvement, the 5-year survival rate falls to around 40%.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. In advanced cases, total penectomy is required with the formation of perineal urethrostomy . Such surgery is indicated even in advanced metastatic disease for reasons of local control. Option: B & C. Tumours affecting the glans penis require glansectomy , with more advanced tumours requiring partial penectomy .

Extraedge:

There are several other benign causes of red patches on the penis; when there is clinical doubt as to the underlying diagnosis a biopsy is indicated. When the diagnosis of carcinoma in situ is confirmed, treatment is by means of topical 5-fluorouracil cream, CO2 laser ablation or surgical excision.

questions.text: At 30- weeks of gestation, the antenatal sac shows bilateral hydronephrosis. Which of the following is the most common location of the posterior urethral valve?

options.label: D
options.text: At the bladder of the neck

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Distal to the verumontanum Distal to verumontanum- there are 3 types of PUV. Type 1 is the valve present distal to the verumontanum. Symmetrical folds of urothelium are seen between the prostatic urethra to the external urinary bladder. These act as a flap- allowing the catheter to pass but not allowing urine to pass.

Highyeild:

Posterior urethral valves Posterior urethral valves are congenital membranes that cause obstruction to the urinary tract in the male Types : Type I - Obstructing membrane that extends distally from each side of the verumontanum towards the membranous urethra where they fuse anteriorly Type II - Described as folds extending cephalad from the verumontanum to the bladder neck Type III Represent a diaphragm or ring-like membrane with a central aperture just distal to the verumontanum Thought to represent the incomplete dissolution of the urogenital membrane Antenatal ultrasound typically shows a distended bladder, dilated prostatic urethra and hydroureteronephrosis Treatment is by endoscopic valve ablation Patients need long-term follow-up in view of recurrent UTI, bladder dysfunction and renal impairment

Extraedge:

If the diagnosis of PUV is not made antenatally, babies typically are presented by parents because of voiding complaints and urinary tract infection (UTI)

questions.text: A 5-year male presents with ballooning of prepuce on micturition . On examination pin point meatus+, was diagnosed as a case of phimosis. Which of the following is not a complication of phimosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Stricture Stricture- it does not occur in phimosis.

Highyeild:

There are physiological adhesions between the foreskin and the glans penis at birth. They begin to disappear around the age of 2 years and may persist until 6 years of age or later, giving a false impression that the prepuce will not retract. This condition (sometimes known as physiological phimosis) should not be confused with true phimosis in a young boy In Boys: In true phimosis, the prepuce does not retract This may result in the ballooning of the foreskin during micturition and may also result in infection (balanoposthitis). In Adults: Scarring in adults occurs as a result of balanitis (inflammation of the glans penis), posthitis (infammation of the foreskin) or LS. In LS the normal pliant foreskin becomes thickened, typically whitish in appearance and forms a constricting band that prevents retraction. As a consequence, it is difficult to keep the penis clean and there may be recurrent attacks of balanitis. Treatment: Physiological Phimosis - No treatment True Phimosis with symptoms - Circumcision Emergency Situations - Dorsal slit under local anaesthesia

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Unable to void fully leads to recurrent balanoposthitis Option: C. Preputial stones formation due to smegma collection in preputial sac Option: D. Carcinoma- late complication

questions.text: A 20-year male presents with penile deformity as shown below. On examination palpable penile plaques within the penis. The image is given below. What is the probable diagnosis
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Peyronie’s disease Peyronie’s disease (plastic induration of penis/ penile fibromatosis Q) is usually seen over 40 years of age. It is due to fibrous plaques in one or both corpus cavernosum of varying sizes involving tunica albuginea which may later calcify or ossify. The cause remains obscure, the dense fibrous plaque is microscopically consistent with findings of severe vasculitis.

Highyeild:

Peyronie’s disease : Peyronie’s disease is characterized by penile deformity, palpable penile plaques within the penis, ED and pain on erection. The cause is unknown but probably involves minor injury to the erect penis with secondary micro haemorrhage beneath the tunica albuginea and secondary fibrosis. The latter results in palpable plaques that can be identified on examination. The plaques may rarely be calcified. The presence of these relatively inelastic plaques causes the erect penis to bend, often dramatically, towards the side of the plaque. The commonest direction of deformity is dorsally (towards the abdomen) and the deformity may be so great as to prevent penetrative sexual intercourse. Clinical Features Painful erection, the curvature of the penis and poor erection distal to the involved area No pain when the penis is in a nonerect state. Palpable induration or mass appears usually on the dorsolateral aspect of the penis. While the aetiology is uncertain, there is an association with Dupuytren’s contracture. The natural history of the condition is that it typically progresses for 18–24 months before stabilizing. During this acute (or active) phase of the disease, surgery is not indicated, and a variety of medical treatments have been tried, although none with any good evidence of benefit.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child is brought to the hospital with complaints of abdominal pain and repeated episodes of fever. USG showed bilateral HUN and distended bladder. The renal parameters are elevated. The investigation of choice for the above congenital abnormality is
questions.explanation:
Solution:

MCU MCU shows a dilated posterior prostatic urethra indicating a Posterior urethral valve which is the most common of congenital urological anomalies in male child.

Highyeild:

Posterior Urethral Valve-Diagnosis Posterior urethral valves need to be detected and treated as early as possible to minimise the degree of renal failure. The presentation varies according to the severity of the obstruction. The more severe the obstruction, the earlier the presentation. Diagnosis is most commonly made antenatally with ultrasound, which demonstrates bilateral hydronephrosis above a distended bladder. Rarely the valves are incomplete and the patient is symptom-free until adolescence or adulthood when again urinary infection or renal impairment can supervene. The investigation will involve a voiding cystogram, with the dilatation of the urethra above the valves demonstrable on a voiding cystogram. The bladder is hypertrophied and often shows diverticula. Typically, there is vesicoureteric reflux into dilated upper tracts. The valves themselves can be difficult to see on urethroscopy because the flow of irrigant sweeps them into the open position. Renal function is usually impaired, albeit to a varying degree, and the extent is further assessed by measurement of ultrasound scanning, which will assess the renal cortical thickness, and renography to assess differential renal function.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Options: A, B & C. Only Renal function can be assessed with routine blood tests and glomerular filtration rate or a DMSA scan

Extraedge:
